values.v_name: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

properties.p_desc: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition that is maintained from generation to generation. Members share a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group. They have similar and distinctive features in their lifestyle habits and shared experiences. They often have a common genetic heritage which may be reflected in their experience of health and disease.
A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.
Age of subject (in days) at the last known survival status.
The stage or period of an individual's disease.
The number of the disease phase.
The type of protocol treatment course administered.
The number assigned to a course of therapeutic agent administration, indicating where a particular course of treatment falls within a sequence of treatments.
The individual's last known survival status.
Age of subject (in days) when the subject was lost to follow-up.
The circumstance or condition that results in the death of a living being.
The type of treatment related to the mortality of the subject.
Specific details of the cause of death.
Assigning a weighted relevance to the cause of death.
A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.
The stage or period of an individual's disease.
The number of the disease phase.

A classification system for acute myeloid leukemias, acute lymphoblastic leukemias, and myelodysplastic syndromes.  It is based on the morphologic and cytochemical evaluation of bone marrow and peripheral blood smears.
A classification of acute myeloid leukemia tumors by the World Health Organization (WHO).

values.v_name: AML with inv(16)(p13.1q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22); CBFB-MYH11
AML with inv(3)(q21.3q26.2) or t(3;3)(q21.3;q26.2); GATA2, MECOM
AML with biallelic mutations of CEBPA
Provisional entity: AML with mutated RUNX1
Myeloid Proliferations Related to Down Syndrome
Myeloid Leukemia Associated with Down Syndrome

properties.p_desc: The method used to detect the extent of the disease involvement.
The anatomic site of the disease.
The status describing the extent of central nervous system involvement at the time of leukemia diagnosis.

An acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage.  It is characterized by the presence of either separate populations of blasts of more than one lineage, or one population of blasts co-expressing markers of more than one lineage.

Acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome occurring in children with Down syndrome.  The acute myeloid leukemia is usually an acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, and is associated with GATA1 gene mutation.

A myeloid proliferation occurring in newborns with Down syndrome.  It is clinically and morphologically indistinguishable from acute myeloid leukemia and is associated with GATA1 mutations.  The blasts display morphologic and immunophenotypic features of megakaryocytic lineage.  In the majority of patients the myeloid proliferation undergoes spontaneous remission.

An acute myeloid leukemia arising from prior myelodysplastic syndrome, myeloproliferative neoplasm, or myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm, or as a result of previous exposure to alkylating agents or topoisomerase II inhibitors.
A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.

The stage or period of an individual's disease.
The number of the disease phase.
The type of protocol treatment course administered.
The number assigned to a course of therapeutic agent administration, indicating where a particular course of treatment falls within a sequence of treatments.
A tumor mass composed of myeloblasts or immature myeloid cells.  It occurs in extramedullary sites or the bone.  (WHO, 2001)
The site of the extramedullary myeloid sarcoma.

values.v_name: FLT3 Tyrosine Kinase Domain Point Mutation

properties.p_desc: One of the bodies in the cell nucleus that is the bearer of genes, has the form of a delicate chromatin filament during interphase, contracts to form a compact cylinder segmented into two arms by the centromere during metaphase and anaphase stages of cell division, and is capable of reproducing its physical and chemical structure through successive cell divisions.
The gene symbol that represents either a single gene that has a mutation or the gene that comprises the 5' portion of the coding sequence involved in a fusion gene mutation.
The gene symbol that represents the gene that comprises the 3' portion of the coding sequence for a fusion gene.
The category or type of variation or abnormality present in an amino acid or nucleic acid sequence.
A variation in the nucleic acid sequence of a specific gene.
A variation in the amino acid sequence of a specific gene product.
An indicator for whether a molecular analysis procedure was performed and whether the assay detected a molecular abnormality.
The determination of the ratio of variant alleles to wild-type alleles present in a sample.

Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.
A substance that inhibits the maturation, growth or spread of tumor cells.
The number of doses.
The total amount of an agent (e.g., drug, biologic, radiation, etc.) administered to a subject over a defined period of time.

A pharmaceutical agent other than agent(s) tested in a given protocol that is administered to or used by a subject either prior to or during the study. Supportive care and essential ancillary medications required by a treatment regimen should be clearly identified. A protocol complete instructions including appropriate indication, dosage, administration route, schedule, restrictions to use, and any other relevant data should be explicitly stated. Concept also refers to substance(s) used prior or during the study that are not specified by the protocol.
The status of the medication administration.

The biological relationship between the stem cell donor and the recipients.

A process in which blood or tissue samples are analyzed to determine their human leukocyte antigen (HLA) profiles so that transplant materials can be transferred into a patient with the same or similar profile.
The number of human leukocyte antigens that were evaluated.
The number of human leukocyte antigens that matched between the donor and the recipient.
The extent of HLA-A matching between the donor and the recipient.
The extent of HLA-B matching between the donor and the recipient.
The extent of HLA-C matching between the donor and the recipient.
The extent of HLA-DRB1 matching between the donor and the recipient.
The extent of HLA-DQ matching between the donor and the recipient.
Type of conditioning the subject received prior to stem-cell transplantation.
A therapeutic procedure that involves the irradiation of the whole body with ionizing or non-ionizing radiation.

A one or more molecular characteristics that are used as a biomarker for minimal residual disease.

Any unfavorable or unintended disease, sign, or symptom (including an abnormal laboratory finding) that is temporally associated with the use of a medical treatment or procedure, and that may or may not be considered related to the medical treatment or procedure. Such events can be related to the intervention, dose, route of administration, patient, or caused by an interaction with another drug(s) or procedure(s).
The code of the adverse event.
The name of the system used to grade the adverse events.

The play-performance scale for children is a parent-rated instrument which records usual play activity as the index of performance.  It is similar to the Karnofsky Performance Scale for adults.
An index designed for classifying patients 16 years of age or older by their functional impairment.
A measure of an individual's overall performance status or ability to perform their activities of daily living.

properties.p_desc: A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.
Age of subject (in days) at tumor assessment.
The stage or period of an individual's disease.
The number of the disease phase.

The classification of a tumor based primarily on histopathological characteristics.
The type of material sample taken from a biological entity for tumor findings assessment testing.
The anatomic site of the tumor.
A qualifier for the side of the body the tumor findings assessment is performed.
The anatomic site within the long bone.
A traumatic injury to the bone in which the continuity of the bone is broken.
The longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.
The second longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a nearly circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.
The third longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a nearly circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.

The International Electrotechnical Commission preferred expression of radiation dose in computed tomography (CT) dosimetry. It is calculated by averaging the radiation dose delivered over x,y and z directions and expressed in the SI unit of Gray (Gy).
An estimate of the volume.
The volume of tumor.
A finding indicating the spread of cancer to a joint.
A finding indicating the spread of cancer to regional or distant lymph node(s).
A benign or malignant pathologic process which is patchy and skips areas which are normal (uninvolved by the pathologic process).
A metastatic tumor nodule located in the same side of the organ in which the primary tumor occurred.

Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.
An examination of cells obtained from a sample of pleural fluid.
The abnormal collection of fluid in the peritoneal cavity resulting in ascites.
An examination of cells obtained from a sample of peritoneal fluid.
The anatomical location where metastasis was detected.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

One of the bodies in the cell nucleus that is the bearer of genes, has the form of a delicate chromatin filament during interphase, contracts to form a compact cylinder segmented into two arms by the centromere during metaphase and anaphase stages of cell division, and is capable of reproducing its physical and chemical structure through successive cell divisions.

A categorization of surgical procedures by type or purpose.
Surgical procedures on a limb.
The surgical removal of all or part of a limb or other appendage.
A procedure to avoid amputation of an arm or leg.
Surgical restoration of function or form of a part.
The degree to which the lesion has been cut out, or resected.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.
Surgical treatment of metastatic disease not involving the lungs.
Surgical treatment of disease metastatic to the lungs.
The process of determining or marking the location or site of a lesion or disease.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

The number of divided radiation doses received per day.
A procedure to move organs out of the range of the damaging effects of radiation.

values.v_name: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

properties.p_desc: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition that is maintained from generation to generation. Members share a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group. They have similar and distinctive features in their lifestyle habits and shared experiences. They often have a common genetic heritage which may be reflected in their experience of health and disease.
A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
A congenital disorder characterized by the presence of extremely hypoplastic gonads preventing the development of secondary sex characteristics.

A risk classification system for extracranial, malignant, pediatric germ cell tumors.
The method used to detect the extent of the disease involvement.

The name of the institution or central histological assessment.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
The percentage of tumor tissue in a sample.
The numeric value for the histology result.
The unit being used as the measurement for the histology test.
Codes for the histologic type of the tumor being reported using ICD-O.

The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.
A nodule of mature glial tissue that develops in the peritoneum. It is usually accompanied by mature or immature ovarian teratoma.
A malignant non-germ cell component that typically develops secondarily within a germ cell tumor. The malignant cellular component is usually sarcomatous or carcinomatous.
A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.

The stage or period of an individual's disease.

The numeric values of the vital signs.

The number of molecules of a particular type on or in a cell or part of a cell. Usually applied to specific genes or to plasmids within a bacterium.
The maximum level that must be exceeded for a certain reaction to occur or be manifested.
The minimum level that must be attained for a certain reaction to occur or be manifested.
A globally unique identifier for a biomedical article, as assigned by PubMed.

One of the bodies in the cell nucleus that is the bearer of genes, has the form of a delicate chromatin filament during interphase, contracts to form a compact cylinder segmented into two arms by the centromere during metaphase and anaphase stages of cell division, and is capable of reproducing its physical and chemical structure through successive cell divisions.
The gene symbol that represents either a single gene that has a mutation or the gene that comprises the 5' portion of the coding sequence involved in a fusion gene mutation.
The gene symbol that represents the gene that comprises the 3' portion of the coding sequence for a fusion gene.
A variation in or modification of the molecular sequence of a gene or gene product.

The determination of the presence of actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient.

Age of subject (in days) at the end of the concomitant medication administration.
The stage or period of an individual's disease.
The number of the disease phase.

A pharmaceutical agent other than agent(s) tested in a given protocol that is administered to or used by a subject either prior to or during the study. Supportive care and essential ancillary medications required by a treatment regimen should be clearly identified. A protocol complete instructions including appropriate indication, dosage, administration route, schedule, restrictions to use, and any other relevant data should be explicitly stated. Concept also refers to substance(s) used prior or during the study that are not specified by the protocol.
A unique identifier for a subject in a Pediatric Cancer Data Commons (PCDC) study.
Age of subject (in days) at the start of radiation therapy.

The number of the disease phase.
The anatomic site of the radiation therapy.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.
The total radiation dose administered.
A unit of measurement of the dose of radiation received or absorbed.
One or more extra radiation treatments targeted at the tumor bed, given after the regular sessions of radiation are complete.
The number of divided radiation doses received per day.

The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.

Any unfavorable or unintended disease, sign, or symptom (including an abnormal laboratory finding) that is temporally associated with the use of a medical treatment or procedure, and that may or may not be considered related to the medical treatment or procedure. Such events can be related to the intervention, dose, route of administration, patient, or caused by an interaction with another drug(s) or procedure(s).

A condition or event that is attributed to the adverse event and is the result or conclusion of the adverse event.

Leukemia with an acute onset, characterized by the presence of lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. It includes the acute B lymphoblastic leukemia and acute T lymphoblastic leukemia.

values.v_name: Acute Leukemia, ambiguous lineage (mixed or biphenotypic)

properties.p_desc: An acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage.  It is characterized by the presence of either separate populations of blasts of more than one lineage, or one population of blasts co-expressing markers of more than one lineage.
Codes for the histologic type of the tumor being reported using ICD-O.
The anatomic site of the disease.
The status describing the extent of central nervous system involvement at the time of leukemia diagnosis.

When the maximum width of a mass is equal or greater than one-third of the internal transverse diameter of the thorax at the level of T5/6 on a PA CXR. Bulk at an alternate site is defined as any mass measuring 10 cm or more by any imaging study.
The subject received steroids within one week prior to diagnosis of the disease phase.
The subject received steroids within one month prior to diagnosis of the disease phase.
